questions.text: Objects communicate with one another by sending _____.
questions.explanation: In object-oriented programming, objects interact by sending messages to each other, which involve invoking methods.

questions.text: ___ are used in cases where we know that the value will never vary during the execution of the program.
questions.explanation: Constants are fixed values that do not change during the program's execution.

questions.text: A(n) _____ is a symbol used within an expression or equation that tells the computer how to process the data.
questions.explanation: Operators define how data is processed and include arithmetic, relational, and logical operations.

questions.text: The minimum number of iterations in a post-test loop is _____.
questions.explanation: A post-test loop (such as a 'do-while' loop) guarantees at least one execution before testing the condition.

questions.text: The relationships between classes are categorized as _____, aggregation, and inheritance.
questions.explanation: Association defines a 'has-a' relationship between classes.

questions.text: The name of an algorithm starts with a(n) _____ letter.
questions.explanation: By convention, algorithm names typically start with a capital letter for readability.

questions.text: Encapsulation can also be referred to as data _____.
questions.explanation: Encapsulation restricts direct access to object data, ensuring it is accessed only through methods.

questions.text: ____ data items may involve organizing them, checking them for accuracy, or performing mathematical operations on them.
questions.explanation: Processing refers to manipulating data to achieve desired outcomes.

questions.text: When multiple choices have to be made, it is better to use the ____ structure that branches on the appropriate set of instructions depending on the value of a given expression.
questions.explanation: Selection structures like 'if-else' and 'switch' statements help make decisions based on conditions.

questions.text: ___ involves repeating the statements contained in a loop body.
questions.explanation: Iteration allows repeating a set of instructions until a condition is met.

questions.text: Operations of a class are also referred to as __Modules___.
questions.explanation: Methods define the behavior and operations that can be performed on an object.

questions.text: The value in the _____ statement is compared to each value following the case statement. If a match is found, the statements following the case are executed.
questions.explanation: The switch statement evaluates a variable and executes code based on matching cases.

questions.text: When using the _____ logical operator, only one of the expressions must be True to yield True.
questions.explanation: The OR logical operator returns true if at least one operand is true.

questions.text: A collection of data stored under a single name is referred to as a _____.
questions.explanation: An array is a collection of elements stored under one variable name and indexed.

questions.text: In computing and mathematics, the term ___evaluate__ is often used to mean 'find the result'.
questions.explanation: Evaluating an expression involves calculating its value based on the given data and operations.

questions.text: Test data must include a sample of every category and must also be _____.
questions.explanation: Comprehensive test data ensures that all possible scenarios are tested, including edge cases.

questions.text: In the ____ structure no steps are left out, and no steps are repeated.
questions.explanation: The sequence structure executes statements in order without repetition or skipping steps.

questions.text: Conditions that determine whether a loop is re-entered or exited are usually constructed with _____ operators.
questions.explanation: Relational operators (like <, >, ==) are used in loop conditions to control repetition.

questions.text: The algorithm is the steps to solve a problem, and the pseudocode is the way in which these steps are expressed.
questions.explanation: Pseudocode is a high-level description of an algorithm used for understanding or planning code.

questions.text: Methods in object-oriented programs use sequence, selection, and looping structures and make use of arrays.
questions.explanation: These structures are fundamental in procedural and object-oriented programming.

questions.text: Conditional structures may not be nested as this will yield various complex program workflows.
questions.explanation: Conditional structures can be nested to handle complex conditions effectively.

questions.text: A hierarchy chart contains details of each module and how the modules are related.
questions.explanation: Hierarchy charts show the relationships between modules in a program.

questions.text: Every file must have an extension.
questions.explanation: File extensions help identify the type of file and its format.

questions.text: Intermediate variables may be used to assist with calculations.
questions.explanation: Intermediate variables hold temporary results, making calculations more manageable.

questions.text: The for loop counter may be incremented or decremented by any number.
questions.explanation: The loop counter in a 'for' loop can be modified by any value (e.g., increment by 2 or decrement by 3).

questions.text: In a loop algorithm that computes non-negative integers, the value '-1' can be set as the sentinel value as the computation will never encounter that value as a legitimate processing output.
questions.explanation: A sentinel value is a special value that is not a valid output, used to terminate loops.

questions.text: The for loop is a good tool when working with arrays because you frequently need to process every element of an array from beginning to end.
questions.explanation: For loops are ideal for iterating through arrays as they allow easy indexing and traversal.

questions.text: A student mark is an example of a numeric field.
questions.explanation: Student marks are represented as numerical values for calculation and comparison.

questions.text: A computer can receive data via a keyboard, scanner, or other input device.
questions.explanation: Input devices allow data entry into a computer system.

questions.text: You use nested if and if/else statements to perform conditional evaluations that must be executed after the original conditional evaluation.
questions.explanation: Nested if statements allow for further decision-making based on previous conditions.

questions.text: A variable name can contain letters and numbers.
questions.explanation: Variable names can include letters, numbers, and underscores but cannot start with a number.

questions.text: If you can write a solution in 200 steps/statements or in 20 statements, clearly the more effective solution is the 20 statement one.
questions.explanation: Efficiency in programming aims to reduce the number of statements without losing functionality.

questions.text: Object-oriented programmers sometimes say an object is one ____ of a class.
questions.explanation: An object is an instance of a class in object-oriented programming.

questions.text: How would you set up the following arithmetic equation? A customer pays 500 Rand for a coffee maker after a discount of 20%. What is the original price of the coffee maker?
questions.explanation: The original price is calculated using the formula: price = final price / (1 - discount/100).

questions.text:
How many lines of output will be displayed when the following code is executed?
display “Hello”
for x = 1 to 4
display “Outer loop”, x
for y = 1 to 6 step 3
if y >= x then
display “Inner loop”, y
endif
next y
next x
display “end”
questions.explanation: The code outputs 11 lines including the nested loop executions.

questions.text: Which of the ‘if’ statements below is the correct one for the following problem statement? To earn a medal in a competition, a participant must cycle at least 20 kilometers and swim 500 meters.
options: A. if cycleDist <= 20 AND swimDist <= 500 then display “July qualifies for a medal” else display “July does not qualify for a medal” endif
B. if cycleDist >= 20 AND swimDist >= 500 then display “July qualifies for a medal” else display “July does not qualify for a medal” endif
C. if cycleDist > 20 AND swimDist > 500 then display “July qualifies for a medal” else display “July does not qualify for a medal” endif
D. if cycleDist <> 20 AND swimDist <> 500 then display “July qualifies for a medal” else display “July does not qualify for a medal” endif
questions.correctAnswer: B. if cycleDist >= 20 AND swimDist >= 500 then display “July qualifies for a medal” else display “July does not qualify for a medal” endif
questions.explanation: The correct 'if' statement checks for equal to or greater than the required values.

questions.text:
Provided below is an if statement. Which of the following select case statements can be used to replace the if statement?

if interest < 1000 then
 tax = 0
else
 if interest <= 2000 then
 tax = (interest – 1000) * 0.075
 else
 tax = (interest – 1100) * 0.095
endif
endif
options:
A. select case
 case < 1000
 tax = 0
 case <= 2000
 tax = (interest – 1000) * 0.075
 case else
 tax = (interest – 1100) * 0.095
 endselect

B. select case interest
 case < 1000
 tax = 0
 case <= 2000
 tax = (interest – 1000) * 0.075
 else
 tax = (interest – 1100) * 0.095
 endselect

C. select case interest
 case < 1000
 tax = 0
 case <= 2000
 tax = (interest – 1000) * 0.075
 case else
 tax = (interest – 1100) * 0.095
 endselect

D. select case interest
 case < 1000
 tax = 0
 case <= 2000
 tax = (interest – 1000) * 0.075
 case
 tax = (interest – 1100) * 0.095
 endselect
questions.correctAnswer:
B. select case interest
 case < 1000
 tax = 0
 case <= 2000
 tax = (interest – 1000) * 0.075
 else
 tax = (interest – 1100) * 0.095
 endselect
questions.explanation: The 'select case' statement in option B correctly replicates the logic of the given 'if' statement.

questions.text: A file type can be represented by:
questions.explanation: The file extension, such as `.txt` or `.docx`, represents the file type.

questions.text:
What would be the value of the variable 'B' in the following pseudocode if the value of variable 'A' is 5.2 and the value of variable 'B' is 15?

if A = 5.2 then
 if B > 20 then
 A = A + 5
 else
 B = B – 3.5
 endif
else
 if A = 6 then
 A = 0
 B = 0
 endif
endif
questions.explanation: The value of B is reduced by 3.5 as it is less than 20.

questions.text: What would be displayed as the daily dosage of medicine to be administered to a dog weighing 4.9 kilograms in the given pseudocode?
options: A. The dog must receive a daily dose of 7.0 ml
B. The dog must receive a daily dose of 9.0 ml
C. The weight must be in kg and to the nearest 500g, e.g., 3, 3.5, or 4
D. The weight must be numeric
questions.correctAnswer: B. The dog must receive a daily dose of 9.0 ml
questions.explanation: Based on the conditions in the pseudocode, the appropriate dosage is calculated as 9.0 ml.

questions.text: The mechanism that binds code and data together and keeps them secure from the outside world is known as:
questions.explanation: Encapsulation restricts direct access to data by bundling it with related methods.

questions.text:
What will be the value of the variable 'x' after the following loop is executed?

for x = 7 to 34 step 5
questions.explanation: The loop will terminate when x exceeds 34, making the last value of x 35.

questions.text: In a group of nested loops, which loop is executed the most number of times?
options: C. All loops are executed the same number of times
D. Cannot be determined without knowing the size of the loops
questions.explanation: The innermost loop completes all its iterations for every single iteration of the outer loops.

questions.text: What is a sequential file used by a program to store new data, by writing it to the file, called?
questions.explanation: An appended file allows new data to be added to the existing contents.

questions.text: Objects often need to hold _____ about themselves.
questions.explanation: Objects hold information or state that defines their properties.
